Introduction

Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by impaired differentiation of mature B cells into plasma cells.  Patients present in adolescence or early adulthood with recurrent respiratory and gastrointestinal infections due to hypogammaglobulinemia, and life-long immunoglobulin replacement therapy is required.

Pathogenesis



Normal B cell development begins in the bone marrow, where hematopoietic stem cells differentiate into immature B cells.  Immature B cells migrate to peripheral lymphoid tissue (eg, spleen, lymph nodes) (

figure 1
).  Upon exposure to an antigen, immature B cells undergo activation, proliferation, and differentiation into plasma cells, as follows:



  • In the absence of T cells, most mature B cells differentiate into short-lived plasma cells that produce antigen-specific IgM antibodies.
  • In the presence of T cells, mature B cells undergo isotype switching (ie, immunoglobulin class switching (

    )) to produce antigen-specific IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies.  After isotype switching, most B cells differentiate into long-lived plasma cells that secrete different classes of immunoglobulins.  Other B cells become memory B cells that remain dormant until the next encounter with the same antigen, when they rapidly generate more plasma cells.


CVID occurs due to impaired differentiation of B cells into long-lived, isotype-switched plasma cells, resulting in hypogammaglobulinemia and increased risk for infection.  Several genetic mutations can cause CVID.  Some mutations cause impaired memory B-cell differentiation and impaired T-cell signaling and cytokine production, along with impaired B-cell differentiation.  In addition to increased susceptibility to infection, immune dysfunction can predispose to autoimmune/inflammatory disorders and malignancy.



Approximately 90% of cases of CVID are sporadic (ie, no family history of the disorder).  Autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive inheritance patterns have been identified, depending on the underlying genetic mutation.  CVID typically presents in adolescents and young adults (ie, age 20-40), possibly related to environmental exposures in a genetically predisposed patient.

Clinical presentation



Most patients with CVID develop symptoms in adolescence or early adulthood.  The presentation can vary and includes:



  • Infection:  Most commonly presents with acute, chronic, or recurrent infections that classically involve the respiratory (eg, pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis) and gastrointestinal tracts.  Patients are particularly susceptible to infection with encapsulated bacteria (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae) because antibody opsonization is required for these pathogens to be recognized by immune cells (eg, phagocytes, macrophages).  Patients are also susceptible to gastrointestinal infections (eg, Salmonella, Campylobacter, Giardia) due to insufficient IgA antibodies.
  • Chronic lung disease:  Occurs in one third of patients with CVID.  Recurrent infection can lead to bronchiectasis (eg, obstructive pattern on spirometry).  Alternatively, immune dysregulation can lead to interstitial lung disease (eg, restrictive pattern on spirometry), with or without granulomata.  Children often develop obstructive airway disease that can be clinically indistinguishable from asthma.
  • Autoimmune disease:  Occurs in one fourth of patients with CVID due to immune dysregulation.  Autoimmune disease can be in the initial presentation, and among these patients, autoimmune hematologic disorders (eg, immune thrombocytopenia, autoimmune hemolytic anemia) are most common.  Other common autoimmune disorders in patients with CVID include rheumatoid arthritis, thyroiditis, and inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Granulomatous disease:  Occurs in 10%-20% of patients with CVID and most commonly involves the lung (eg, dyspnea on exertion, cough).  It can also involve lymph nodes, spleen, and liver (eg, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly).
  • Chronic gastrointestinal disease:  Occurs in 10%-20% of patients with CVID and leads to chronic diarrhea with malabsorption and failure to thrive in children or weight loss in adults.

Diagnosis



CVID should be suspected in patients with recurrent bacterial infections involving the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.  Physical examination may be normal or show signs of chronic illness (eg, failure to thrive/weight loss, tympanic membrane scarring, digital clubbing).  Laboratory evidence of hypogammaglobulinemia (eg, low IgG in combination with low IgM and/or IgA) and impaired immune response to protein- and polysaccharide-based vaccines is required for the diagnosis.



  • Hypogammaglobulinemia:  Quantitative immunoglobulin assay shows low IgG (ie, <400 mg/dL) in combination with low IgA and/or IgM.  IgE is undetectable in most patients.
  • Impaired immune response to vaccines:  Markedly reduced or absent tetanus- and diphtheria-specific IgG antibodies show impaired immune response to protein-based vaccines.  Similarly, markedly reduced or absent pneumococcal-specific IgG antibodies show immune response to polysaccharide-based vaccines.


Additional testing that can support the diagnosis of CVID includes flow cytometry (shows normal total circulating B and T cells but deficient memory B cells) and genetic testing (only 30% of patients have a genetic mutation associated with CVID).  Routine laboratory testing (eg, complete blood count, serum electrolytes) is normal in the absence of complications (eg, infection, autoimmune cytopenias).



CVID is a diagnosis of exclusion; therefore, other immunodeficiencies and secondary causes of hypogammaglobulinemia (eg, protein loss from renal disease, long-term glucocorticoid use) must be excluded prior to diagnosing CVID.

Differential diagnosis



Primary causes of hypogammaglobulinemia:



  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia:  Presents with severe bacterial infections in infancy due to impaired early B-cell maturation.  Similar to CVID, laboratory testing shows hypogammaglobulinemia and impaired immune response to vaccines; however, flow cytometry shows markedly decreased or absent circulating B cells (ie, CD19+)
  • Transient hypogammaglobuniemia of infancy:  Characterized by low IgG, IgA, and IgM levels during infancy but can persist into early childhood.  Because patients eventually produce normal immunoglobulins, serial laboratory testing is required for children age <6 with suspected CVID.
  • Hyperimmunoglobulin M syndrome:  A condition in which B cells cannot isotype-switch from IgM to other immunoglobulins.  As a result, patients have normal or elevated IgM, whereas IgG and IgA are low.
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency:  Characterized by markedly low T cells with varying numbers of circulating B cells.  Because helper T cells play a role in B-cell activation, patients may have decreased antibody production in addition to impaired cell-mediated immunity.  Patients tend to present in early infancy with severe bacterial, viral, and fungal infections.


Secondary causes of hypogammaglobulinemia include malignancy (eg, leukemia), use of immunosuppressive or antiepileptic medications, and gastrointestinal and renal protein loss.

Management



The primary goal of CVID management is to prevent infection.  Strategies include:



  • Immunoglobulin replacement therapy (eg, intravenous immunoglobulin):  Presently the most effective strategy for preventing infection.  Immunoglobulin replacement therapy can also delay progression to chronic lung disease in some patients.
  • Antibiotic therapy:  Should be initiated early during an infection to prevent chronic complications.  In addition, prophylactic antibiotics are indicated for patients with recurrent infections despite immunoglobulin replacement therapy (particularly important in those with recurrent pulmonary infections to prevent chronic lung disease).
  • Vaccinations:  Although the immune response to vaccines is impaired in patients with CVID, inactivated vaccines are still recommended given the possibility of reinforcing T-cell immunity to viral pathogens.  Because the degree of immune impairment varies, some patients may be able to form antibody-specific immunoglobulins in response to the vaccine.  Live vaccines are contraindicated.


Patients should also be closely monitored for signs and symptoms of noninfectious complications (eg, autoimmune disease, vitamin deficiencies) that may require chronic immunosuppressive therapy (eg, corticosteroids); however, immunosuppressive therapy increases the patients' risk for infection.  Finally, patients with CVID are at increased risk for malignancy, and patients should undergo all routine, age-appropriate cancer screening.  Additional testing should be performed for suspected malignancy (eg, drenching night sweats, progressive lymph node enlargement, dyspepsia with unexplained weight loss).

Prognosis



With immunoglobulin replacement therapy, the risk of mortality from infection in patients with CVID has decreased significantly.  Currently, the major causes of mortality are chronic lung disease (eg, bronchiectasis, immune-mediated interstitial lung disease) and malignancy.  Prompt diagnosis and compliance with immunoglobulin replacement therapy are essential for a favorable diagnosis.

Summary



Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) (

) is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by impaired differentiation of mature B cells into plasma cells, resulting in hypogammaglobulinemia.  Patients present in adolescence or early adulthood with recurrent respiratory and gastrointestinal infections.



CVID is a diagnosis of exclusion that requires laboratory evidence of hypogammaglobulinemia (eg, low IgG in combination with low IgM and/or IgA) and impaired immune response to protein- and polysaccharide-based vaccines.  Complications include chronic lung disease, chronic gastrointestinal disease (eg, malabsorption), autoimmune disease (eg, immune thrombocytopenia, rheumatoid arthritis), and malignancy (eg, lymphoma, gastric cancer).  Management involves life-long immunoglobulin replacement therapy and close monitoring for life-threatening acute infections and complications.
